article.title: Genomic Characterization of Potential Plant Growth-Promoting Features of Sphingomonas Strains Isolated from the International Space Station

funding.text: 2012 Space Biology NNH12ZTT001N grant number 19-12829-26 under task order NNN13D111T

article.abstract: In an ongoing microbial tracking investigation of the International Space Station (ISS), several Sphingomonas strains were isolated.

sections.introduction: Sphingomonas species are found in a variety of habitats, including soil, marine sediments, wastewater, and freshwater, in addition to the habitats contaminated with dyes, herbicides, and other pollutants (1â€“3).
sections.methods: Sample collection and processing, followed by WGS and assembly that led to the isolation of Sphingomonas strains, are described elsewhere (25, 63).
sections.results: Among the cultivable bacteria, three colonies obtained from ISS surfaces (IIF7SW-B3A and IIF7SW-B5) and one from KSC (FKI-L5-BR-P1) were identified as Sphingomonas species.
sections.discussion: This study shows the identification of putative PGPFs in Sphingomonas strains isolated from the ISS or in a cleanroom where spacecraft are assembled.

article.insights_summary: This study identified putative plant growth-promoting features in Sphingomonas strains isolated from the International Space Station.
article.acknowledgments: Part of the research described in this publication was carried out at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under a contract with NASA.
